newsitem.title: USA: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS/Netscape busy, volatility rises.
newsitem.headline: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS/Netscape busy, volatility rises.

text.p: Options on shares of Netscape Communications Corp were busy in morning trading as the stock fell sharply after its rating was cut by Merrill Lynch.
The brokerage firm lowered its near term rating to neutral from accumulate and its long-term rating to neutral from buy.
At 1045 CDT (1545 GMT), shares of the Internet browser developer were down 3-3/4 at 42-1/4 on 2.1 million shares. The stock, which closed at 46 on Tuesday, reached a low of 41-1/4.
One trader at the CBOE said investors were selling Netscape calls and buying puts off the opening, driving up the volatilities.
The trader said most of the activity was in small lots from retail discount brokerage firms.
Netscape options trade on four of the five options exchanges, but most of the activity was split between the American Stock Exchange and the Chicago Board Options Exchange.

On the AMEX, the most active Netscape option was the October 45 put, which traded 1,430 contracts, with one block of 1,400 crossing. With the stock down, the option rose 1-1/2 to five. Its open interest was about 4,250.
Traders said Morgan Stanley crossed the 1,400 block.
The same option on the CBOE traded just 38 contracts.
But the October 40 put traded 200 contracts. It was up 15/16 at 2-7/16 and had open interest of nearly 3,700.
Marty Kearney at PTI Securities said volatility on the October puts had risen to the low- to mid-70 range from a historical level around 62.
A big pop in volatility was seen in the September puts, which went to the 80-90 zone.
"The (September) puts are a little rich," Kearney said. "People are a little worried as to how quickly this goes down and what kind of followthrough there'll be."
The September 40 put, with volatility around 90, was up 7/16 at 9/16 and traded more than 500 contracts on the AMEX and about 400 on the CBOE, where it added 1/4 to 3/8.
Volatility on the September 45 put was up to 80. On the CBOE, the option was up two at 2-3/4 and traded 200 contracts. Its open interest was about 660.
The trader on the CBOE floor noted that after the early spike in volatility, trading settled down as the stock stemmed its decline.
"We'v started seeing buyers of calls again," he said. --G.Crawford, (312) 408-8750/E-mail: derivatives@reuters.com
